title: Germany Bribes FIFA Executives In 2006 World Cup Vote
text:
Sports News | 17 October 2015 11:48 CET Germany Bribes FIFA Executives … In 2006 World Cup Vote By Daily Guide 
Germany tried to create a £7million ‘slush fund’ to help land the 2006 World Cup, reports in the country claim. 
Weekly news magazine SPIEGEL alleged that high-ranking officials including Bayern Munich icon Franz Beckenbauer were aware of a loan made to secure the four votes belonging to Asian representatives on the 24-man FIFA Executive Committee. 
The German Football Association (DFB) responded on Friday to insist the â‚¬6.7m payment by the organising committee was not in exchange for votes to secure the right to stage the tournament. 
The DFB say its own investigation into the payment had found no evidence of wrongdoing. 
SPIEGEL claim the decision to award the World Cup to Germany was ‘likely bought in the form of bribes’. The allegations centred around the notion that then-Adidas CEO Robert Louis-Dreyfus secretly filled a slush fund with 10.3 million Swiss francs. 
Beckenbauer, head of the organising committee, and Wolfgang Niersbach, current head of the DFB, are said to have been aware of the fund from 2005 at the latest. 
Louis Dreyfus is alleged to have lent the illicit funds to the bidding committee prior to the World Cup vote on July 6, 2000, but it never appeared in their budget and was used to bribe FIFA officials.
